Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: Humans and the Marine Environment: Fishing through Time in Monterey Bay, CA

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Under the supervision of Dr. Diane Gifford-Gonzalez, Cristie Boone will analyze how humans and the marine environment interacted over 8,000 years on the central coast of California, emphasizing the role fishing played in subsistence decisions. Fish are a key resource found in the region's archaeological sites, yet are often treated as a homogeneous category, rather than the biologically and behaviorally diverse resource they are. The different technologies and skill-sets necessary to catch them are rarely considered. This project examines how fish compare to other human foods, and how the role of fish in the diet changes over time and space. Ms. Boone's analysis will focus on identification of fish species from archaeological bones. It will also obtain nutritional analyses of commonly encountered species to construct prey rankings, and conduct direct radiocarbon dating of specimens to control for the effects of gophers and other rodents on archaeological site stratigraphy. Results will be combined with data on past marine and terrestrial environments to assess human responses to major climatic events.

Archaeology and anthropology have used human behavioral ecology and optimal foraging theory (OFT) to investigate human subsistence for some time. This project introduces a modeling technique, long used in ecology but only minimally applied to anthropology, that permits more nuanced explorations of OFT models than currently performed. Dynamic state variable modeling expands the number of factors that can be included within an analysis, and can provide more realistic foraging predictions. This model can be expanded and applied to numerous archaeological contexts where people had to consider trade-offs between decisions.

This project will address the multiple and sometimes divergent scenarios for the Monterey Bay's human prehistory. In a broader perspective, it explores how fishing interacts with other subsistence behaviors in a coastal hunter-gatherer setting and its relation to the emergence of social complexity.

Currently fisheries management is attempting to prevent the world's fish populations from declining to the point of complete collapse. Archaeological research is recognized as a valuable source of long-term data to describe fish population characteristics from pre-industrial fishing contexts. Preliminary findings from analyzed assemblages already indicate that some species may be smaller today than they were in the past.

This project's educational impacts include providing important laboratory opportunities for undergraduates. Several undergraduates have been trained in archaeological fish analysis and preparation of fish comparative skeletons. One student created her own research project using the assemblages and, under Ms. Boone's instruction, analyzed fish remains from two sites, presenting her paper at the Santa Clara Undergraduate Research Conference in 2008.

Research will be presented at regional and national archaeological conferences, published in peer-reviewed journals, and a digital database and the modeling code provided for public use.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research used California’s Monterey Bay as a case study for analyzing human decisions in acquiring marine fishes through different climatic regimes during the last 8,000 years. Using fish bones from archaeological sites, I addressed behavioral, ecological, and biological aspects of fish species that affect their value to human diet. I also critically examined local evidence for Holocene climate changes. I questioned the common archaeological assumption that energy (calorie) return over time is the key variable in ranking prey species, and employed dynamic state variable modeling, long used in ecology, to predict optimal diet decisions. I then assessed how prior descriptions of California Central Coast culture history compare to climatic evidence, model predictions, and my faunal analysis results.

My analysis of fish remains from 13 Monterey Bay Area sites sampled multiple habitats and cultural periods over eight millennia, and produced data on species distributions, fish bone modifications, and fragmentation. I radiocarbon dated fish specimens from each site to assess how these agreed with dates on other materials, and analyzed nutritional compositions of several nearshore species to elucidate the role of nutrition in prey selection.

Dynamic state variable modeling results suggest that three variables are very important in determining a forager’s prey choices: the probability of successful prey capture, a forager’s mortality risk while gathering food in a particular habitat, and energy expended. The model predicts that foragers preferentially exploit predictable, easily acquired resources, even when those have relatively lower rates of return in calories. This prediction is borne out by the results of my archaeological analyses and suggests that we need to reconsider our traditional assumptions about optimal foraging decisions.

Fish faunas show statistically significant shifts in type of prey taken in similar habitats over time. Sharks and rays are abundant only in the earliest estuary sites, most likely declining due to natural degradation of that habitat by silt accumulation over centuries. Tidepool fishes rise from a common but low frequency food to nearly a third of all identified specimens in the last thousand years, suggesting that Native Californians continued to be heavily dependent on marine resources right up to historic contact.

Sardines are common over time and come to dominate the faunal assemblages of later precolonial periods. Their abundance increases markedly during the Medieval Climatic Anomaly (AD 800-1400), a time of unusual climate in the northern hemisphere that caused droughts and higher temperatures in much of California and would have limited terrestrial plant productivity as well as animal sources of fat. Paleoclimatic evidence indicates that, while the Medieval Climatic Anomaly strongly affected the land environment, marine conditions remained rather stable. The higher proportions of sardines during the MCA suggests they may have been valued for their fat content, which is substantially higher than any of the other species analyzed.

Overall, my research indicates that people did not always acquire the nearest and most easily caught prey, as previous studies have suggested. People sometimes sought valued fish species in more difficult and dangerous habitats and responded to changes in habitat and climate.

Outcomes have so far been presented at the 2012 Annual Meetings of both the Society for American Archaeology (April 18-22) and Society for California Archaeology (March 29-April 1), and were also part of presentations at the 2013 Annual Meetings of the Society for California Archaeology (March 7-10).
